description: First "University Settlement" to open Sept 1884. Arts, community & heritage space. Grade II. Heritage refurbishment (2019) includes new entrance/café, repairs and lighting to chapel and roof terrace.

factsheet.heading: Victorians and all that: From Settlement House to Art and Community Centre
paragraphs: The architect of Oxford House was (Sir) Arthur William Blomfield (1829-1899), son of the Bishop of London, a prominent high churchman who founded several churches in Bethnal Green. Blomfield was the architect of the Royal College of Music and the rebuilding of Southwark Cathedral, London and several colleges at Cambridge. But in comparison with his former projects, he worked to a smaller budget than his usual commissions and in a more cramped, urban location.

The architecture of Oxford House was in the domestic style of the 16th or 17th century. The Duke of Connaught inaugurated the Victorian building in 1892. The ceremony was attended by the Archbishops of Canterbury and York, six bishops and other ecclesiastical luminaries, underscoring the settlement's religious purpose.
Since 2011 Oxford House has been listed as a Grade II building by English Heritage.

factsheet.heading: Extension
paragraphs: Adapting to new needs, Oxford House was extended to the east after the Second World War, to provide a new hall. In 2003, this extension was replaced with a two-storey building by All Clear Designs Ltd. The new building extension and refurbishment provided a theatre and studio space, with a link structure running along the north side of Oxford House providing level access, a new entrance foyer and gallery spaces.

factsheet.heading: Exterior
paragraphs: Oxford House is a three-storey building, plus a basement and an attic, in a spare Tudor Revival style. The building is constructed of red brick with brick chimneys and a tiled roof. The southern façade is symmetrical, of seven bays with shallow two-bay cross-wings under pitched roofs with gables of stone hexagonal ball finials, coping and kneelers. The original entrance doors are up a short flight of steps; a foundation stone on the recessed porch wall records November 30th 1891. On the right hand side of the entrance is a Victorian post box set embedded into the wall. To the west is the former clubhouse of 1894, of three bays with a hipped roof. The outer ground-floor bays of the clubhouse, now windows, were originally the entrance doors. A new ramped entrance from Derbyshire Pocket Park was created in 2019.

factsheet.heading: Interior
paragraphs: Since its building the interior of Oxford House has been remodelled several times. However, the solid brick walls are largely in the original configuration. Furthermore, panelled door reveals and fireplaces survived the last century. A large Tudor-arched fireplace with carved rosettes in the spandrels stands out. It is located in today’s café, the former dining room of the graduates, on the ground floor. The original student’s bedrooms on the 1st and 2nd floor are currently used as office space for charities and social businesses.

factsheet.heading: Chapel
paragraphs: The chapel is located on the 3rd floor; it is the best-preserved room of the building. The chapel is panelled in wood. The east end features a timber altar and a timber triptych. The latter comprises a central painted panel flanked by carved doors.

The painting, by Alfred U Soord dated 1914, depicts the crucifixion. The inner faces of the doors are decorated with coloured and gilt paint and show subjects from the Old Testament (to the left) and the symbols of the Evangelists (to the right). The paneling to the rear of the chapel is inscribed with names of the Fallen of the First World War. There are various plaques affixed to the paneling which commemorate the lives of people connected with Oxford House. The restoration of the original Chapel was completed in 1997 with further significant refurbishment in 2019 following water damage from the roof.

factsheet.heading: Arts Centre
paragraphs: The 2003 extension houses, a new entrance foyer (now used only for events), the Oh! Arts Centre. This includes gallery space for various exhibitions and workshops, a theatre with bar area, a dance studio and new lift.

Oxford House provides a range of weekly performing arts programming for young and older people. The spaces are also used for professional theatre, dance and filming companies for rehearsals and filming.

factsheet.heading: Refurbishment 2019
paragraphs: The refurbishment programme was completed during the summer of 2019.

The £3.24 million project was funded by National Lottery Heritage, Tower Hamlets Council, Power to Change and several other trusts and foundations. Following procurement in early 2018 Rooff Limited, were selected as the main contractor. Practical completion took place in June 2019.

The refurbishment works included:
- New entrance from Pocket Park + café/welcome space
- Spiral staircase to new roof terrace
- Major repair to tiled roof + new covering to roof terrace 
- Refurbishment of chapel 
- New lift to the chapel and 3rd floor
- Creation of  Settlement Room for events and training
- Extra accessible toilets on 3rd floor
- Redecoration + repair to original leaded windows, brickwork + chimneys
- Beefed up infrastructure (central heating, electrical upgrades, CCTV and phone/fibre system)
- Removal of asbestos
Heritage England announced in October 2019 that Oxford House was removed from the Buildings at Risk Register following the works.
